hazards. Grants are made to fix
broken windows, patch chimneys.
repair roofs, and make other
repairs to provide the family with
minimum housing.


Other loans may be made for
rental housing. Direct loans are
made at low interest rates to
nonprofit organizations to finance
housing for the elderly in the low
and moderate inc ONE groups. One
recent loan of $l82. 900 was used
by nonpr oft corporation no build
81 apartments.


A similar loan is available on
an insured basis to individuals
or commercial corporations. A
builder in New Jersey built 20
one-and two-bedroom apart
ments last year. He borrowed
from a nearby band and USDA
insured the loan. The apartments
we're designed for older people
and include such features as
grab bars and nonslip floors in
the bathroom, and easy access
to cabinets and equipment.


The elderly are the fastest
growing group in our national
population. Their needs will be
given more attention in the future.
The Agriculture Department has
made modest beginning inhelp-
ing to finance housing for the
elderly in rural areas. More In
formation may be obtained from
the local county representative
of the USDA's Farmers Home Ad-
ministration. He is usually To-
Gated at the county seat.

An assistant secretary of COM
merce for economic policy re-
view told the annual conference of
the National Ass ociation of Mar
ket Developers that the Negro
market is changing because Of
increased income and employ
ment opportunities.


He said on the basis of study
that the income of Negro families
has caused an emergence of
larger middle class spending ha-
bit pattern.


Evidences Of upgrading in the
consumption behavior or Negro
families is shown by the follow
ing percents for 1850 and 1860:

automobiles 7 per cent-9.5.


He further stated that the num-
Der of Negroes engaged in the
marketing field is concentrated
in industries and activities which
are disappearing or becoming
crowded.


Of the 400 NAMD members,
more than four-fifths we're SAL
aried employees. More than one
third we're concentrated in the
distribution of food and bever-
ages, or allied fields. A ma jority
were employed In alcoholic bev-
erages or soft drinks divisions.


Other fields represented we're
automobiles, travel and petro-
leum products.


Only 10 per cent we're asso-
ciated with communications me-
dia. About 4 per cent we're en-
ployed with public relations
firms.


STOP AND SHOP AT
TRIBUNE ADVERTISERS

Few Negroes Advance in
Murke ting Fields in u. S.

Nearly one third OF the 10
million people over o5 In the
United States live in rural areas.
Four million of these older rural
people live in small towns ana
about a million and a hall live
on farms.


Housing problems for the eld-
erly range from the need for
smaller, more convenient units
to undermining, and maintaining
present housing, much OF which
is below standard.


Retirement housing is different
in rural areas and cities. Most
rural people live in single fam
ily houses. When farmer re-
tires, he generally has to move.
This means he must buy, build
or rent. If he builds, few cred
itors other than USDA would
make a long term loan. because
of his age. Several loan programs
are offered to help these people.


One is direct loans at low In
terest rates, for people over o2
who can take care of their own
homes. These kinds of borrowers
may use co-signer. such as a
son or daughter, If the parent
does not have enough income to
repay the loan. Rural people over
81 may also borrow to buy a used
home, if it is in good repair and
fits their needs.


For those elderly rural people
who own home but don't have
enough income to repay a loan
a small grant can be made to make
the home safe and remove health
